intro: Ipomopsis multiflora subsp. brachysiphon, commonly known as the narrow-siphon ipomopsis, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its tubular, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in open habitats such as sagebrush steppe and grasslands. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. This subspecies is often found in arid environments and is adapted to thrive in low-nutrient conditions.
